title: league is not about kills, it is about not dying.
body:
Every time I've been in a losing game the single thing that stands out is that the game was lost because people wanted kills. If they had played "safe" and lived, we'd have won.

How many kills you have means nothing if you lose. Don't die!

No, League **isn't** about not dying! Neither is it about kills. It is about Objectives.
Not dying does shit for you and your team if it means you just surrender one objective after another and never play pro active. No risk no gain, and while you shouldn't go overboard on the risk, never risking anything simply gets you nowhere at all.

Most bad players i see in my games are bad because they follow that stupid don't die idea. It's those adc that are to afraid of anything so they get a total of 3AAs done in a teamfights and then run away as only survivor, ending the game with less damage dealt to champs than their support.
It's those malphits that stay behind their carries till the end of the fight and then use the ult to kill a low health target and run away afterwards.

Sometimes tradeing your laife for something bigger is a good thing, even a needed thing.
Drawing 3-4 man top as splitpusher and evt dying is perfectly fine **IF** your team can get dragon+tower or something like that on the otherside of the map, as they are 4 vs 1-2.
Initiateing a fight often ends with a death for the initiator, but a won fight for your team. Unless you play a counterengage comb, ahveing the initative on your side and chooseing when and how to engage is a big advantage, but people that are afraid of dying often will hesitate to engage when the opportunity shows, as that often would mean you loose 1-2 members, but take3+from them, which leads to a powerplay on your team, leading to objective, which then lead to victory.

Sure, chaseing for kills and dying over it is a bad idea, but generally saying not dying is the key is just as wrong.

Of course it is about objectives. But you can' take a turret if you are dead. You can't get CS if you are dead. You only fed the enemy (unless executed) if you are dead. And yes, sometimes it is worth it. But when there are a ton of deaths on a team, it usually means that people have been greedy in some way ... not playing for the team, dying when they could have given a kill to a team member and lived, being so tied up in what they are doing they don't see the big picture.

One thing about 'dying less'.  Dying isn't always a condition of YOUR mistake.

It's all about how the Team works with you.

Sometimes the RIGHT decision is to Hard Engage (say a Braum, or a Malphite, or a Leona).  So you do.  You set it up perfectly.  While your team runs away.

In this scenario let us assume the ADC was out of position and easy to pick off, and that doing so didn't risk putting your ADC or APC in danger... you made the absolute 100% correct play.  But the Team didn't follow.

Now with your 4 Friends on Curse, you make the call and go all in... and your Team gets an Ace, AND you live.  

In one, you are an idiot who dies to much and the team rages you... in the other you are the hero who made the set up for the Ace.  But the trick is, it's the EXACT same situation.  Reality is you were RIGHT both times, but your team failed you in one while they supported you in another.

In other words, if you simply play not to die... then when you play with Teams that communicate and do the right things, you'll play at a Disadvantage and won't be as useful to the Team.

The key is to make the right choices for the right reasons.

ok, to the people who say this is false:  It is completely about not dying.

The problem with "playing safe" is that those players don't know when it's safe and when it's not safe, so everything is not safe.

By "Not dying", the idea isn't pushing needlessly to get a kill.  It's about not overextending just for a few extra gold.  It means not chasing someone under a turret when you're low, and not facechecking the brush just because you saw a weak laner flee through them.  It's about taking calculated risks, not needless ones.

It's about making your opponent die just as much as it is making yourself not die.

This is why good bottom laners don't engage without each other - solo is an unnessecary risk, and together, at the right time, is a calculated risk.

This is why, as a Sup, I leave my ADC to die.  They took a risk without me, dove at a bad time, and I'm not rushing in to try to save them because their risk was uncalculated because they thirst for kills, and mine says "nope, bad time, we gon' get ganked, they haven't been poked enough to make it worthwhile, and I'm not giving 2 kills" (aside: I play Leona and E relatively aggressively).

There is a difference between aggressive and reckless.  There is also a diference between safe and recklessly safe.  Yes, that is a thing.

And THAT is why it's abut not dying.  More specifically, not being reckless, either on offense or defense.
